docs.title: SDE Interview Prep 2026
docs.text: Systematic preparation for coding interviews covering DSA, System Design, and behavioral preparation.

docs.title: 📊 DSA Prep
docs.text:
Data Structures & Algorithms practice with detailed solutions, complexity analysis, and pattern identification.

Goal: 100+ problems over 115 hours Status: In progress

docs.title: 🏗️ System Design
docs.text:
High-level and low-level design patterns with case studies, tradeoff analysis, and architectural principles.

Goal: Master 10+ design patterns in 30 hours Status: In progress

docs.title: ☕ Java & Spring
docs.text:
Concurrency patterns and Spring Boot best practices for interview preparation.

Status: Optional - Based on company tech stack

docs.title: 🎯 How to Prepare - Interview Guide Insights
docs.text: Based on analysis of "You Suck At Coding Interviews" - a comprehensive guide from former Apple and Uber engineers with 70% success rate with coaching clients.

docs.title: 1. The Magic Bullet Trap ⭐ MOST COMMON
docs.text:
Problem: Jumping straight to optimal solution, failing when wrong, wasting 20+ minutes.

Fix: Always start naive → optimize incrementally → test baseline. Your Takeaway: In interview, propose naive first, get feedback, then optimize.

docs.title: 2. Not Testing on Paper
docs.text:
Problem: Algorithm works in your head but fails in reality.

Fix: Trace through 2-3 examples on paper BEFORE coding. Real Example: Reversing linked list [4,5,1,3,2] - works in head, fails on paper.

docs.title: 3. Speed ≠ Understanding ⭐ CRITICAL
docs.text:
Problem: L4 interviews need 15min, L5 needs 3-5min. If not autonomous, redo the topic.

Benchmark: - L3: 30+ minutes - L4: 15 minutes - L5: 3-5 minutes

Fix: Track time per problem, watch for improvement curve.

docs.title: 4. Only Memorizing Solutions
docs.text:
Problem: Watch solution, move on. Can't apply to variations.

Fix: For EACH solution, reverse-engineer: - What problem characteristics led here? - What inefficiencies existed in naive? - What insights bridge naive → optimal?

Outcome: 20 deeply understood problems > 100 memorized problems

docs.title: 5. Pattern Confusion Overlap
docs.text:
Problem: After learning many patterns, preconditions overlap and confuse you.

Fix: After learning new pattern, backtest against previous 5 problems. Timeline: Spend 30 min per new pattern on overlap checking.

docs.title: 6. The Sliding Window Trap
docs.text:
Problem: Memorize "use sliding window for subarrays" without understanding WHY.

Fix: Learn the PRECONDITION: "Can reuse portion of previous result"

docs.title: 7. Skipping Edge Cases in Planning
docs.text:
Problem: Code first, realize edge cases after. Wastes time, causes bugs.

Fix: BEFORE coding, list all edge cases: - Empty input, single element, duplicates, negatives - Extreme values, already sorted/reverse sorted

docs.title: ⚠️ The 7 System Design Gotchas to Avoid
1. Premature Component Specification ⭐ MOST COMMON
docs.text:
Failure Pattern:

❌ "We'll use MongoDB, Redis, Nginx..."
Interview: "Why?"
Your Answer: "Because... it scales?"
Interviewer: ❌ FAIL

Fix: Start with PROBLEM characteristics, then JUSTIFY tech choice.

Correct Pattern:

✅ "We need to store non-relational data with horizontal scaling.
   MongoDB provides this by sacrificing consistency for availability."

docs.title: 2. The Free Lunch Fallacy
docs.text:
Myth: "NoSQL scales better"

Truth: NoSQL trades consistency/joins for scale - no magic.

Tradeoff Matrix:

Aspect MySQL NoSQL Joins ✅ Fast ❌ Complex Scale ⚠️ With sharding ✅ Native Consistency ✅ Strong ❌ Eventual Simplicity ✅ ❌

Your Takeaway: EVERY choice costs something. Name the cost.

docs.title: 3. Not Calculating Capacity ⭐ CAUSES WRONG DESIGN
docs.text:
Example Calculations:

500M URLs/month ÷ 30 days ÷ 86400 sec = 200 writes/sec
100:1 read/write ratio = 20,000 reads/sec
Each entry ~500 bytes
3 years retention = 18B URLs × 500B = 9TB

Insight: 9TB = needs sharding. 200 writes = probably fine on single server IF no sharding

Your Action: ALWAYS calculate: DAU, QPS, storage, bandwidth FIRST

docs.title: 4. Missing Non-Functional Requirements
docs.text:
What Most Candidates Do: Only plan functional (create, read, delete)

What You Must Do: Also define: - Latency requirement (milliseconds?) - Availability/SLA (99.9%? 99.99%?) - Consistency model (strong? eventual?) - Throughput needed (requests/sec?)

Example Failure:

Candidate: "We store URLs in database, cache in Redis"
Interviewer: "If Redis dies?"
Candidate: "Use the database..."
Interviewer: "Latency impact?"
Candidate: "Goes down?"

Better:
"If Redis dies, fallback to database (slower)
We set 1-second timeout so app doesn't hang
We alert on Redis failure to rebuild quickly"

docs.title: 5. Ignoring Failure Scenarios
docs.text:
Failure Types: - Network: Server A can't reach Server B → Timeout? Retry how many times? - Replica Lag: Write on primary, read stale replica → How old acceptable? - Cascading: Service A slow → timeouts → Service B backed up - Data: Disk fails → Need replication

Your Mitigation Strategy: Timeouts, circuit breakers, fallbacks, monitoring

docs.title: 6. Not Discussing Tradeoffs Explicitly
docs.text:
Failure: Propose solution, move on.

Success: State what you're sacrificing for each choice.

Example - Sharding Strategy:

Option Pro Con Hash-Based Even distribution Redistribution nightmare Range-Based Easy to add servers Potentially uneven Directory-Based Handles uneven Directory becomes bottleneck

Right Answer:

"I'd use hash-based sharding initially for even distribution
(acknowledging risk of uneven load in production)
With monitoring to detect hot shards
If observed, migrate to directory-based despite complexity"

docs.title: 7. Not Justifying Each Component
docs.text:
Failure: "Load balancer, API gateway, queue, cache, database..."

Success: Can you explain WHY each component exists in one sentence?

Correct Framework:

Problem → Solution → Component (justified)

Problem: 1M requests, single server can't handle
Solution: Multiple servers + distribute requests
Component: Load balancer ✅ (justified)

Problem: Latency from database lookups
Solution: Store frequent queries in fast memory
Component: Redis cache ✅ (justified)

Problem: Spike traffic causes failures
Solution: Buffer requests, process asynchronously  
Component: Message queue ✅ (justified)

docs.title: DSA: 115 Hours Total
docs.text:
Hours Phase Material Goal Milestone 0-35 Foundations Grokking (skip DP) 80%+ pass rate Easy problems < 10 min 35-50 DP Mastery Grokking DP course Can solve DP Easy/medium < 20 min 50-85 Advanced EPI ch 5-16 All solvable All problems solvable 85-115 Practice LeetCode medium 70% first try Interview ready

Practice Diary (MANDATORY): For every problem, record: - Time spent - Mistakes made (with ROOT CAUSE) - Decision chain that caused mistake - Actionable prevention steps - Related problems for pattern reinforcement

docs.title: System Design: 30+ Hours
docs.text:
Phase Hours What Why Study Solutions 0-15h Grokking: 5-10 case studies Learn patterns Understand Theory 15-25h DDIA key chapters Understand WHY Reverse Engineer 25-30h Design similar systems Can apply independently Interview Ready 30h+ Can handle L4/L5 interviews Demonstrate mastery

Key DDIA Chapters: - Ch 5: Replication (data copying, consistency models, replica lag) - Ch 6: Partitioning (sharding, rebalancing, cross-partition problems) - Ch 9: Consistency & Consensus (CAP theorem, algorithms) - Ch 11: Stream Processing (events, message queues, real-time)

docs.title: DSA: Are you ready to apply?
docs.text:
• [ ] Completed 60%+ of Grokking
  • [ ] Completed EPI chapters 5-16
  • [ ] Can solve 70% of 20 random problems first try
  • [ ] Can solve ANY problem with infinite time
  • [ ] Only mistakes are weird situational facts, not core patterns
  • [ ] Practice diary filled with 50+ problems
  • [ ] Can speed-run 5 problems in 45-60 min total

docs.title: System Design: Are you ready?
docs.text:
• [ ] Studied 5-10 case studies deeply (Grokking)
  • [ ] Read DDIA chapters on your weak areas
  • [ ] Can explain WHY each system design choice made
  • [ ] Can calculate: DAU, QPS, storage, bandwidth
  • [ ] Can identify failure scenarios and mitigations
  • [ ] Can state tradeoffs explicitly
  • [ ] Never say tech name without justifying

docs.title: Mindset Shifts Required
docs.text:
• [ ] Shift from "memorization" to "understanding"
  • [ ] Shift from "speed" to "consistency"
  • [ ] Shift from "complexity" to "simplicity"
  • [ ] Shift from "patterns" to "preconditions"
  • [ ] Shift from "tech stacks" to "reasoning"

docs.title: 🎯 Key Learning Principle
docs.text:
"Avoid mistakes rather than seek excellence. Not making ANY mistakes beats trying to be brilliant and failing."

Apply this to both DSA AND System Design. Consistency > Speed

docs.title: 📖 The Practice Diary Template
docs.text:
**Problem:** [Name]
**Time Spent:** [XX minutes]
**Result:** [Success/Partial/Failed]

**Mistakes:**
1. [Specific mistake]
   - Why made: [Root cause]
   - Cost: [How much time lost?]
   - Prevention: [Actionable step for future]

**Decision Chain:**
A → B → C → Mistake
   (Which decision was bad?)

**Fix:**
"Next time, I will [specific action]"

**Insights:**
- [Pattern learned]
- [Related problem to revisit]

**Similar Problems:**
- [Problem 1] - Similar because [reason]
- [Problem 2] - Different because [reason]

Last Updated: February 15, 2026 Based On: "You Suck At Coding Interviews" comprehensive analysis Status: 📚 3 repos created, interview prep system operational
